conclusion: Understanding the setup: a hollow insulated cylinder with two chambers separated by an insulating diaphragm, both filled with gaseous helium at the same initial pressure, volume, and temperature.
The piston is moved upwards slowly, suggesting a quasi-static process where the system remains close to equilibrium.
The expansion of the gas is adiabatic due to the insulation, and for an ideal gas, PV^γ = constant, where γ is the adiabatic index.
For helium, which is a monatomic gas, γ = 5/3.
The diaphragm is sealed initially, preventing gas from leaking between the chambers.
As the piston moves upwards, the pressure in the upper chamber decreases because its volume increases.
The lower chamber remains at the initial pressure until the diaphragm lifts off the ledge, allowing gas to leak between the chambers.
The leakage starts when the pressure in the upper chamber drops below the initial pressure p, causing the diaphragm to lift off the ledge.
The upper chamber's volume increases adiabatically as the piston moves upwards.
The displacement of the piston is denoted by x, affecting the height and volume of the chambers.
The cross-sectional area A of the cylinder is V / (2H).
The volume of the upper chamber after moving the piston upwards by x is V_upper = V + (V / (2H)) x.
The volume of the lower chamber becomes V_lower = V - (V / (2H)) x.
The initial position of the diaphragm is at height H from the bottom, so each chamber has volume V = A H.
When the piston is moved upwards by a distance x, the upper chamber's new volume is V_upper = A (H + x).
The lower chamber's new volume is V_lower = A (H - x).
The total volume remains 2V, which is A (2H).
The upper chamber expands adiabatically, so its pressure decreases according to the adiabatic relation: p_upper = p (H / (H + x))^(5/3).
Initially, both chambers are at the same pressure, volume, and temperature.
As the piston moves upwards, the upper chamber expands adiabatically, causing its pressure to drop.
